labels.value: ALT is a protein found throughout your body, but mainly in your liver and kidneys. ALT helps with producing energy for your body. This test measures the amount of ALT in your blood sample. ALT is measured to check the health of your liver.
Hi ##Contact! You have been assigned as a Delegate for ##UserName. Thank you for joining ##UserName on their journey through the ##StudyName Study.

If have not received a packet, travel support may not be available at your study center and you should check with a member of your study team. By clicking OK, you are consenting to participate in the travel support service and leaving the Patient Portal website. The Terms of Use and Privacy Policy on other websites may be different from those of this website. Please refer to the Privacy Policy and Terms of Use of these other websites as we cannot control or be responsible for their policies, terms of use, or legal/regulatory compliance.

labels.value: AST is a protein found throughout your body, but most is found in your heart and liver. AST is released by the cells in the liver or muscles when they are damaged. This test measures the amount of AST in your blood sample. AST is measured to check the health of your liver.

By subscribing to an institution-based Referral Network, you agree to being automatically notified via email when a new study site begins enrolling at that institution and that you may be contacted occasionally regarding clinical study-related news or events at that institution. By subscribing to a topic-based referral network, you agree that you may be contacted when a clinical study related to that topic becomes available.
Survey tasks will expire when the Participants status is changed to: Drop Out, Trial Complete or Participation Complete

Albumin is a protein made by the liver. It helps to keep fluid in the bloodstream so that fluid does not leak into other tissues. It also transports certain substances, such as hormones, vitamins, drugs, and calcium. This test shows the amount of albumin in your blood sample. Albumin is measured to check the health of your liver and kidneys.

Alkaline phosphatase is a protein present in multiple parts of your body, but most is found in your bones and liver. In the liver, it helps to digest fat. It also helps to create bones. Alkaline phosphatase is measured to check the health of your liver and bones.

labels.shortDescription: BTN View terms and conditions participant

labels.value: Urea is a waste product of the liver. The liver changes ammonia (a toxin) into urea. Urea is removed from bloodstream by the kidneys and then leaves the body through urine. Nitrogen is a substance present in urea. This test measures the amount of urea and nitrogen in your blood sample to check whether your kidneys are working properly.
BMI is a measure that shows a person’s weight to height ratio. It is calculated by dividing your weight in kilograms (kg) by the square of your body height in meters (m).

Calcium is an electrolyte (a mineral) that is important for the functioning of your muscles, including your heart, and nerves. Calcium is also needed for blood clotting and for creating and keeping your bones and teeth healthy. This test measures the amount of calcium in your blood sample. Calcium is measured to check your general health and can be used to check for a range of conditions.

This site uses ##cookiesURL for the essential functioning of the site and for analytical purposes. For more information about these cookies, please view our ##privacyPolicyURL. By clicking through to our website, you are accepting use of cookies.
This site uses cookies for the essential functioning of the site, to improve user experience, and for analytical purposes. By closing this cookie message, you are agreeing to our use of cookies.

Creatinine is a waste product of the muscles. Creatinine is removed from the blood by the kidneys and then leaves the body through urine. This test measures the amount of creatinine in your blood. Creatinine is measured to check the health of your kidneys.

The first step is for you to enroll.

We are reaching out to you on behalf of the Study Team to let you know that we have received your information and that a member of the Study Team will contact you regarding the next steps in the enrollment process.
To assist you in tracking where you are in the clinical research study referral process, as well as to allow you to learn more about this study and future clinical research opportunities, we encourage you to enroll in the IQVIA Referral Hub and Patient Portal.
Please note that enrollment in IQVIA Patient Portal is not a requirement to be enrolled into the research study: ##StudyName.

Glucose is a sugar, also called “blood sugar”. When your body digests food, carbohydrates are broken down to make glucose. Your small intestine then absorbs the glucose to release it into the blood. Glucose is the most important source of energy for cells in your body and the only source of energy for your brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Blood glucose is measured to check your general health and to check for a range of conditions.

A hematocrit test measures the proportion of red blood cells in your blood. Your blood is made up of different components, such as red and white blood cells and blood platelets. The hematocrit value is the ratio of the volume of red blood cells compared to the total volume of all the components of the blood together. This value is expressed as a percentage. For example, if your hematocrit value is 50%, it means that there are 50 milliliters (mL) of red blood cells in 100 mL of blood. Hematocrit is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence red blood cells.

Hemoglobin is a protein that contains iron. Hemoglobin can be found in all red blood cells and it is what makes your red blood cells look red. Its main responsibility is to carry oxygen through the body. A hemoglobin test measures the amount of hemoglobin that is present in your blood sample. Hemoglobin is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your hemoglobin level.
Your height is the measurement of your body from head to foot in centimeters (cm) or feet and inches.

A hematocrit test measures the proportion of red blood cells in your blood. Your blood is made up of different components, such as red and white blood cells and blood platelets. The hematocrit value is the ratio of the volume of red blood cells compared to the total volume of all the components of the blood together. This value is expressed as a percentage. For example, if your hematocrit value is 50%, it means that there are 50 milliliters (mL) of red blood cells in 100 mL of blood. Hematocrit is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence red blood cells.

Hemoglobin is a protein that contains iron. Hemoglobin can be found in all red blood cells and it is what makes your red blood cells look red. Its main responsibility is to carry oxygen through the body. A hemoglobin test measures the amount of hemoglobin that is present in your blood sample. Hemoglobin is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your hemoglobin level.

Lipoproteins are made of a combination of lipids (fats) and proteins. High-density lipoproteins (HDL) are produced by the liver and move cholesterol from the liver to other body parts. HDL cholesterol cleans the walls of your cells and it removes LDL cholesterol from your blood. HDL cholesterol is also known as “good” cholesterol.

Lipoproteins are made of a combination of lipids (fats) and proteins. Low-density lipoproteins (LDL) are produced by the liver and move cholesterol from the liver to other body parts. LDL cholesterol is also known as “bad” cholesterol. When your LDL cholesterol is high, it means it can build up in the walls of your blood vessels and block the blood flow.

labels.shortDescription: You are already associated with this study.
labels.value: You are already associated with this study.
Add Patient and View Study Details

Click Add Patient to enter details for your patients who may participate in the study so they can access our Patient Portal to track their progress and view information related to their participation, or if you simply want to manage and track your patient referrals in the platform along with those sent to you from other recruitment sources via Referral Hub. Click on Study Name to see more details, such as inclusion and exclusion criteria, and access other functions associated with the study.
Manage individual referral statuses. Click on the patient name to access fields for recording contacts, changing referral status, and making notes.

Manage the status of Referring Providers who have requested to refer to your study site. Click Invite Referring Provider to enter contact information for colleagues from whom you would like to receive referrals through Referral Hub so that we can invite them to the platform.
If you have more than one role in the Referral Hub, you can easily switch between roles using the dropdown selector at the top right corner of the screen.

Click Search for More Studies to access a list of available studies, find study sites, and request the ability to refer patients to a Primary Investigator. Click the study name to view more details about the study. Click Pre-eligibility Screening to begin the referral process, even if you have not yet been accepted by a Principal Investigator. Click Associated Sites and Site Details to view sites to which you have requested to refer for that study.
Access study details here. Share this study with another Referring Provider. Click Refer to this Study to be guided through the patient referral process.
Begin the referral process for your patient by going through the pre-eligibility screening.

Use the filters to select studies, study sites, and date ranges. Click Export to download your data. If you are prompted with a window indicating that the file format and extension do not match, click Yes to open the file.

View status of patients for whom you have completed a pre-eligibility screening but not yet referred in the top section of the screen and the status of patients who you have referred to a study in the bottom section of the screen.
Click on the Help menu to view the application walkthrough again and access other application resources.
Add Team Members and Modify Permissions

Click on your user profile icon to access My Team. Add new members to your team by clicking on Add New Team Member. Manage an existing team member’s permission for all studies by selecting a permission level and saving it on the team member’s card.

Click on your user profile icon to access Account Settings. In addition to managing your contact information, date and language preferences, and cookie settings, you can also choose the type of email notifications you want to receive. In the Email Preferences section, use the toggles to switch on or off the type of emails you want to receive. In the Referral Networks section, click Select Referral Networks to search and subscribe to institution-based and/or topic-based networks to be notified when a related study site or clinical study becomes available or to be contacted occasionally about related news or events.

labels.shortDescription: OT H Medical Record Review Log

labels.value: Click on your user profile icon to access My Team. Add new members to your team by clicking on Add New Team Member. Manage existing team member's permissions for individual studies using the dropdowns.
Accept both Referrals and Referring Clinics directly on this page.

Click "DETAILS" on the Status Card to view your status activity history. Take action on tasks that have been assigned to you or created by you or your delegate using the Open Task List. View study documents and other resources including articles and videos related to the study or the condition being studied from Resources.
Click Details to view more information about your participation in the study.

Click "My Study" to view the Study Workspace which includes information about the study in which you are taking part, such as inclusion and exclusion criteria and study site details. The expanded Tasks and Resources pages are also accessible from this area.
Click "Help" to access resources for guidance on using the portal.
Click on Study Name to see more details, such as inclusion/exclusion criteria.
Click on the "profile" icon on the top right of the page to manage your Account Settings including password and contact information, personal preferences, as well as Delegates.
If you have more than one role in the Referral Hub, you can easily switch between roles using the dropdown selector at the top right corner of the screen.
Add Team Members and Modify Permissions

Click on your user profile icon to access My Team. Add new members to your team by clicking on Add New Team Member. Manage an existing team member’s permission for all studies by selecting a permission level and saving it on the team member’s card.
Refer patients who passed the medical record review to the study site. Note that some studies do not require a medical record review.
View overall status of past referrals. Refer eligible patients directly from this page.

Click on your user profile icon to access Account Settings. In addition to managing your contact information, date and language preferences, and cookie settings, you can also choose the type of email notifications you want to receive. In the Email Preferences section, use the toggles to switch on or off the type of emails you want to receive. In the Referral Networks section, click Select Referral Networks to search and subscribe to institution-based and/or topic-based networks to be notified when a related study site or clinical study becomes available or to be contacted occasionally about related news or events.

Please check your cookie settings below and turn on any cookies you’re happy with. "Strictly necessary" cookies can’t be turned off. However "Functional" cookies can be turned on or off below.

labels.shortDescription: PP L Account Setting Preferred Lng
labels.value: Please select your preferred language for Patient Portal. English will be displayed if a translation is not available for your preferred language.
<<Replace this text to approved>> (Study Site don't have Visit Plan)

Platelets, also known as thrombocytes, are tiny parts of cells in the blood that are responsible for blood clotting. They made by your bone marrow and released into your bloodstream. When you are injured, platelets will help to stop the bleeding. The platelet count test shows the number of platelets you have in your blood sample. Platelet count is measured to check your general health and to check for any conditions that influence your body’s platelet production. Low platelet count can be caused by certain cancers, chemotherapy, and in some autoimmune conditions.
Please confirm that your patient has signed ICF consent

Potassium is an electrolyte (a mineral) that helps to transport nutrients into cells and waste products out of cells. It also lets muscles and nerves to communicate with other muscles and nerves. Potassium is measured to check the balance of your electrolytes.

Red blood cells (RBCs or erythrocytes) are cells in your blood that contain hemoglobin, which carries oxygen throughout your body. RBC count is the total number of red blood cells that are present in your blood sample. RBC count is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your body’s red blood cell production. Low RBC count can lead to signs of anemia, such as tiredness. High RBC count can cause dizziness and headache.

labels.value: Your recipient will receive a link to this article or video on ClinicalResearch.com
Respiratory rate is a measurement of how many breaths you take per minute.
Add a Member To Your Team
Study Site information was successfully saved
Please make sure that you entered valid email address

Sodium is an electrolyte (a mineral) that can be found in all bodily fluids. It is important for proper functioning of your muscles and nerves. Sodium is measured to evaluate the balance of your electrolytes.
Don't see a study that you could refer your patients to?

You will need to give some blood, which will be used to check your health and to see how your body responds to and processes the study medication. In the optional genetic research sub-study, blood samples will be used to see how genes affect the way the study medication works.

These are checks of your general health and may be brief or a complete examination. At the visits during the treatment period, you have a brief physical examination. This will include skin, lungs, heart and blood vessels, and abdomen. At the screening and follow-up visit, you will have a complete physical examination. This will include skin, heart and blood vessels, stomach and intestines, airways and neurological assessment (nerves), and any other necessary checks. Your height and weight will also be measured.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your chest to check the health of your lungs. You will have this test once between Weeks 48 and 51.

The study doctor will perform a procedure during which sticky pads are placed on your chest, arms, and legs. The pads are connected by wires to a machine that checks the rhythm and activity of your heart.
Before some visits, you will need to fast (not eat or drink anything, except water) for at least 6 hours before the visit.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your hands and feet to check the health of your joints.

An appropriately trained person (or doctor or nurse) will examine your joints and count how many are swollen and/or tender, by pressing on your joints with their fingers/hands. The pressing on the joints may cause some discomfort and pain for any joints that are tender.
This test will be performed to measure the amount of air you have in your lungs and how well you can move that air by forcibly blowing into a spirometer (lung function machine).

The study doctor will check the health of your lungs and any coughing by listening to the sound of your breathing with a stethoscope. They will also ask you about any breathlessness and measure the amount of oxygen in your blood.

If you take part in contRAst-X, the long-term extension study, you will not have this follow-up visit.

If you are a woman who is able to get pregnant, you will have a pregnancy test at regular intervals during the study. The test at screening will be a blood test and the remaining tests will be urine tests. The effects of the investigational medication on unborn babies is not known.

You will be asked some questions about your health in general, your sleep, your pain and energy level, and how RA is affecting your daily life. There are also optional participant questionnaires, where you can provide feedback about your experience in the study.

You will speak to a member of the study team who will ask you questions about your health, any medications you have taken, and how you are feeling. This will happen every 1 to 4 weeks and may be done by phone or at the study center.
You will receive enough study medication to last until your next visit. You will also receive information on how to take and store the study medication.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
You will receive the study medication capsules every 4 weeks. You will also receive information on how to take and store the study medication.

You will receive the study medication injection at the study center. For visits at Study Weeks 0, 1, 12 and 13, you will need to stay at the study center for 1 hour after you have received the study medication injection. For visits at Study Week 3, 5–7, 9–11, 14, 15, 17–23, 25–35, 37–47, 49–51 you may be able to self-administer the study medication injection at home. Your study doctor will let you know whether this option is available. If you self-administer the study medication injection, you will receive a supply of pre-filled syringes every 4 weeks.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas sed euismod enim. Curabitur consectetur nunc eget nisi fringilla dignissim. Cras auctor felis aliquet imperdiet pulvinar. Sed semper vestibulum nisl, sed porttitor quam.
You will be asked to provide urine samples, which will be used to check your health.
Your blood pressure, heart rate, breathing rate, and body temperature, will be measured.
The study doctor will perform a test that takes an image of the inside of your chest (to check the health of your lungs) and hands and feet (to check the health of your joints).

Please be aware that you will be redirected to the travel service setup and will need a travel service packet in order to complete the process. If you have not received a packet, travel support may not be available at your study center and you should check with a member of your study team.
By clicking OK, you are consenting to participate in the travel support service and leaving the IQVIA TM Patient Portal website. The Terms of Use and Privacy Policy on other websites may be different from those of this website. Please refer to the Privacy Policy and Terms of Use of these other websites as we cannot control or be responsible for their policies, terms of use, or legal/regulatory compliance.

Systolic blood pressure is a measure of how hard your blood is pushed against the walls of the arteries when the heart is beating and pushing out blood.

Cholesterol is a type of fat made by the liver that is found in your blood. You can also take in cholesterol by eating certain foods, such as meat, fish, eggs, and dairy products. Your total cholesterol value is the sum of your low-density lipoprotein (LDL, or “bad” cholesterol) and your high-density lipoprotein (HDL, or “good” cholesterol) and your triglycerides.

Proteins are important for growth and development of the body by helping to make tissues and cells. The total protein test measures the total amount of two types of protein, albumin and globulin, in your blood sample. Total protein is measured to check the health of your liver and kidneys.

Triglycerides are a type of fat found in your blood. Your body uses triglycerides to give you energy. When you eat too many calories, your body will store these calories as triglycerides to use later. Most fats that we eat, such as animal fats and trans fats, are triglycerides. However, the body also produces triglycerides from the carbohydrates that we eat. When your triglycerides are high, they can build in the walls of your cells and block the blood flow, just like LDL cholesterol.

Triglycerides are a type of fat found in your blood. Your body uses triglycerides to give you energy. When you eat too many calories, your body will store these calories as triglycerides to use later. Most fats that we eat, such as animal fats and trans fats, are triglycerides. However, the body also produces triglycerides from the carbohydrates that we eat. When your triglycerides are high, they can build in the walls of your cells and block the blood flow, just like LDL cholesterol.

White blood cells (WBC or leukocytes) are cells that can be found in your blood and in body tissues that are important for your immune system (your body’s defense responses). WBCs fight infections, cancer, and also remove poison, waste products, and damaged cells from your body. When you are fighting off an infection, the number of white blood cells increases. WBC count is measured to check your general health and to check for conditions that influence your body’s white blood cell production. A high WBC count can mean you have an infection.
Your weight is the measurement of your body mass in kilograms (kg) or in pounds.
